column4: You need to add them to the group 'root'  (or edit the sudoers file using visudo.. but that's getting complicated.)
sudo adduser <username> admin     is this what i need?
That could do it
great!
sudo adduser <username> admin  gave me output about adding the user to the group root. i still get: sudo: must be setuid root   when trying to run stuff with sudo.
Did you look at the ownership and permissions on the sudo executable?
It shows that someone did at some point screw up the permissions on your sudo file.  It should be -rwsr-xr-x 2 root root 145K 2010-04-13 18:37 /usr/bin/sudo
run this: sudo chmod u+s /usr/bin/sudo
mgolisch it's a new EC2 instance
let me try
so sudo chmod u+s /usr/bin/sudo  will not helpL
It will be helpful, but it might not be able to run without booting off of a CD image.. because you can't seem to execute sudo commands.
your command helped! so what is the s i see here: -rwsr-xr-x
it changed from x to s
If it changed from x to s.. that's probably fixed it.
yes, but what does it mean?
That command set the SUID bit. (Well. the "user sticky" bit really.. but in that instance..that's what it does.)  Can you run sudo without the error now?
yes
Well, that seems to solve that. :)  Whee!
it's a production machine so i want to make sure it's secure and i know what i did.
Well, if you want to make sure you know what you did, you want to make sure you turn on a lot of logging for sudo.. and you should avoid doing a sudo su - to get to a root shell. ;)
ok. thanks a lot!
